TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen , born in DATE and currently resident in GPE , GPE . Before the ORG he is represented by Ms. PERSON , legal adviser at FAC , GPE .
On DATE the applicant was convicted at ORG of threatening behaviour likely to cause harassment , alarm or distress , contrary to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE . He was fined £ MONEY .

The applicant appealed . His appeal was heard on DATE at ORG by a judge and CARDINAL lay justices . The appeal was dismissed , and the court adjourned the sentence for full psychiatric and medical reports for DATE . The court remanded the applicant in custody for that period , without considering whether to grant bail . It appears that the conditions for remanding the applicant in custody under LAW DATE were not satisfied , and that the applicant was entitled to bail .

Prior to remanding the applicant in custody , the judge enumerated the applicant 's previous convictions . The applicant had been conditionally discharged for DATE after CARDINAL of these . The applicant admitted being in breach of the conditional discharge . No action was taken in respect of this breach either by ORG or by ORG .

On DATE the applicant appeared before the same judge . The psychiatric report revealed nothing material and the judge purported to pass a sentence of DATE imprisonment retrospectively . Defence counsel pointed out that the offence under LAW was not punishable by imprisonment . The judge then imposed a conditional discharge for DATE ( in substitution for the previous sentence ) .

In a letter to ORG dated DATE , ORG stated that , in their view , the learned judge had indeed erred and counsel for the respondent had regrettably failed in his duty to assist the learned judge . The applicant was granted legal aid to make an application to ORG for judicial review of the judge 's decision to remand him in custody . On DATE the application for judicial review of the remand in custody for psychiatric reports was granted . ORG made a declaration in the following terms : “ that the applicant 's remand in custody was unlawful ” .

On DATE , the applicant ’s solicitors addressed a request to the Lord Chancellor 's Department for “ substantial damages by way of compensation for his unlawful imprisonment ” . On DATE , ORG informed the solicitors that it could not pay compensation , as ex gratia compensation from ORG was limited to cases where “ the court staff are guilty of maladministration or negligence ” . It indicated that ORG could not pay compensation for loss or damage arising from judicial decisions .
An opinion from counsel of DATE confirmed that no action lay against the Lord Chancellor 's Department , and added that , similarly , no action lay against the judge , the justices , ORG or ORG .
